newsitem.title: New Zealand: NZ debt markets end unchanged, look to wages data.
newsitem.headline: NZ debt markets end unchanged, look to wages data.

text.p: Figures in brackets compare against previous day's close
FUTURES PHYSICAL YIELD (PCT)
90-DAY BILLS (JUN) 93.05 (PREV 93.07) 90-DAYS 6.97 (PREV 6.96)
OVERNIGHT CASH 6.90 PCT (PREV 6.90) US 5-YR 6.48 (PREV 6.51)
NZ MCI vs -0.81 vs -0.77
* NZ debt markets end unchanged
* Talk of 5-year eurokiwi bond issue on the way
* Market awaits private sector wages data on Thursday
New Zealand debt markets barely moved on Wednesday, with little on the domestic front to nudge yields in either direction.
A steady Trade-Weighted Index held the short end firmly in check, while bond yields slowly gave away early gains to end on Tuesday's closing levels.
An auction of index-linked bonds and private sector wages data on Thursday could provide a short-term lead, dealers said.
"The TWI was steady all day, and it has really been a TWI-following market. There's nothing in the offshore markets to move it, there's been no axes to grind," a dealer said.
The 90-day bank bill rate closed a point higher at 6.97 percent.
In the bond market, yields were marked down a couple of points at the open on the back of a further rally in U.S. Treasuries overnight, but then spent the rest of the day drifting off.

One senior Wellington bond dealer said the 2002s were bought first up as talk of a five-year eurokiwi issue circulated the market. "There's a lot of talk, but we haven't seen any evidence of it yet," he said.
New Zealand bonds are expected to take their lead from the U.S. market in the near-term, with U.S. non-farm payrolls data on Friday, well after the New Zealand close, a key indicator.
But the release on Thursday of private sector average hourly ordinary time earnings will be watched with interest by the debt markets for signs of inflationary wages pressure.
The private sector wages data, due out at 10.45 a.m. (2245 GMT) are part of Statistics New Zealand's Quarterly Employment Survey, the rest of which remains scheduled for June 12.
An auction of NZ$50 million of February 2016 bonds during Thursday morning could also raise some interest as some players expect it to be the last stock in the series to be issued.
-- Matthew Brockett, Wellington Newsroom (64 4) 473-3736
